author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Republican Rift on Ukraine Could Undercut U.S. Appeals to Allies
description: G.O.P. leaders are attacking President Biden for what they call a weak response to Russian aggression, but their far-right flank is questioning U.S. involvement, and even its alliance with Kyiv.
content: WASHINGTON — As President Biden tries to forge a united allied response to Russian aggression in Ukraine, unity on the home front is strained by a Republican Party torn between traditional hawks in the leadership and a wing still loyal to Donald J. Trump’s isolationist instincts and pro-Russian sentiment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Gandel
title: As stocks swing, bonds send a more ‘orderly’ signal about the future.
description: Some strategists think that bond markets might be a better indicator of what’s next for the economy.
content: Stock markets took investors on another wild ride on Tuesday, plunging, recovering and then dropping again. The S&P 500 opened 1.5 percent higher on Wednesday, but what does that mean after a week of such stock swings?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Trevor Noah Weighs In on Biden’s Hot Mic Drop
description: “You see? This is what happens when you have been on Zoom calls for two years — you forget that real life doesn’t have a mute button,” Noah said of the president’s comments about a Fox News reporter.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: Oura Ring 3 Review: A Missed Opportunity for Wearable Tech
description: At a time when we are concerned about health, the smart ring, which can track sleep and body temperature, is too flawed to recommend.
content: There couldn’t be a better time for wearable technology to shine. In the coronavirus era, we’re all concerned about our well-being. So wearable computers with tiny sensors that offer insight into our health seem particularly useful.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Sweden’s Songwriters Dominated U.S. Pop. Now, They’re Looking to Korea.
description: Dozens of songwriters and producers in Stockholm make a living from K-pop — even if they can’t speak Korean.
content: When the Swedish songwriter Ellen Berg first heard a K-pop track, in 2013, her reaction was typical of many Western listeners: “What the hell is this?” she recalled thinking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcelle Sussman Fischler
title: House Hunting in France: A Diamond in the Rough Near the Basque Coast
description: In the seaside resort town of Biarritz, home buyers are skewing younger as families replace tourists, further crowding an already teeming market.
content: This nine-bedroom, Neo-Basque-style villa sits on a grassy 1.85-acre lot in Winter Park, a quiet residential district outside of downtown Biarritz, the resort town on France’s Basque coast, near the border with Spain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Creswell
title: Disney Princess dolls are reunited with Barbie.
description: Mattel announced it had won back the license to produce dolls and toys based on the popular movie characters, like Anna and Elsa from “Frozen.”
content: Barbie and Elsa are buddies again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: U.K.’s Other Health Crisis: A Huge Backlog of Delayed Non-Covid Care
description: The free health care system was known for delays, caused in part by whittled-down funding. But Covid made waits for transplants, cancer treatments and other essential care even longer.
content: LONDON — Lara Wahab had been waiting for more than two years for a kidney and pancreas transplant, but months had passed without any word. So last month she called the hospital, and got crushing news.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Can the West Stop Russia From Invading Ukraine?’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about the unfolding conflict between Russia and Ukraine, and consider what is at stake for the rest of the world.
content: Featured Article: “Can the West Stop Russia From Invading Ukraine?” by Dan Bilefsky
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Man Admits He Tried to Smuggle 2 Men Into U.S. in a Coffin
description: At a checkpoint in Texas in October, federal prosecutors said, Border Patrol agents found two men from Mexico hidden in a coffin.
content: A Texas man pleaded guilty on Tuesday to attempting to smuggle two men from Mexico into the country in a flag-draped coffin, a crime that federal prosecutors said had been uncovered by a couple of U.S. Border Patrol employees who happened to be military veterans and sensed that something was amiss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gretchen Reynolds
title: Walking Just 10 Minutes a Day May Lead to a Longer Life
description: Ten minutes of moderate exercise daily would prevent more than 111,000 premature deaths a year, a new analysis found.
content: If almost all of us started walking for an extra 10 minutes a day, we could, collectively, prevent more than 111,000 deaths every year, according to an enlightening new study of movement and mortality. Published this week in JAMA Internal Medicine, the study used data about physical activity and death rates for thousands of American adults to estimate how many deaths every year might be averted if everyone exercised more. The results indicate that even a little extra physical activity by each of us could potentially stave off hundreds of thousands of premature deaths over the coming years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Justice Breyer to Retire From Supreme Court
description: The decision gives President Biden a window to fulfill a campaign pledge to nominate a Black woman to the court.
content: WASHINGTON — Justice Stephen G. Breyer, the senior member of the Supreme Court’s three-member liberal wing and a persistent if often frustrated advocate of consensus as the court moved sharply to the right, will retire upon the confirmation of his successor, people familiar with the decision said, providing President Biden a chance to fulfill his pledge to nominate a Black woman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Woo
title: John Arrillaga Sr., Who Helped Build Silicon Valley, Dies at 84
description: Starting in the 1960s, he developed the area’s farmland into office parks that housed fast-growing technology companies.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — John Arrillaga Sr., the real estate developer who physically transformed Silicon Valley into tech office parks from orchards and became a major donor to Stanford University, died on Monday in Portola Valley, Calif. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Caldwell
title: Robbinsville, N.J.: A Diverse Community ‘at the Center of It All’
description: The Mercer County township in the middle of the state is growing rapidly, but there’s still plenty of open space.
content: The township of Robbinsville, N.J., has a long history, but it has been known by its current name for less than two decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Awaiting Report on Parties, Johnson Faces Fire Over an Afghan Evacuation
description: Email messages made public by Parliament suggest the British prime minister authorized the evacuation of cats and dogs from an animal charity, despite denying doing so.
content: LONDON — Awaiting a report into lockdown-breaking parties in Downing Street that could force his resignation, Prime Minister Boris Johnson was on the defensive Wednesday over another issue — whether he authorized the evacuation of cats and dogs from Afghanistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: America Has Split, and It’s Now in ‘Very Dangerous Territory’
description: Why crises like Covid don’t unite us anymore.
content: Why did the national emergency brought about by the Covid pandemic not only fail to unite the country but instead provoke the exact opposite development, further polarization?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Democrats can seat a new justice on their own, even if Republicans unite in opposition.
description: Recent changes in Senate rules mean a nominee can be confirmed with a bare majority, but Democrats will have to hold their narrow ranks together.
content: WASHINGTON — Democrats could confirm a successor to Justice Stephen G. Breyer without any Republican support under Senate rules that shield a Supreme Court nomination from a filibuster, but would have to hold their bare majority together to do so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: YouTube Bars Right-Wing Media Personality Dan Bongino
description: Already suspended under the platform’s Covid-19 misinformation rules, he continued to post videos daring YouTube to ban him.
content: YouTube said on Wednesday that it had terminated accounts associated with Dan Bongino, a popular right-wing radio and Fox News host, nearly two weeks after it first suspended his channel for violating its Covid-19 misinformation policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Kasakove
title: In California, a New Fight to Stop Building in the Path of Fire
description: A proposed luxury development in hills already scarred by wildfire is raising questions about the continued push to build in areas at highest risk.
content: MIDDLETOWN, Calif. — When Pat Donley learned about the proposed 16,000-acre luxury development that would border her ranch in the burn-scarred hills of Northern California, her mind raced back to the terrifying hour she spent in bumper-to-bumper traffic while fleeing the Valley fire in 2015, as a barrage of flames advanced down either side of the road.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: ‘Civil Rights Queen,’ the Story of a Brave and Brilliant Trailblazer
description: Tomiko Brown-Nagin’s book is the first major biography of Constance Baker Motley, the first Black woman to serve as a federal judge, among other achievements.
content: How do you measure progress? The incrementalist counsels patience: Something is better than nothing, half a loaf is better than none.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: For Michael K. Williams, a Legacy Interrupted
description: Williams died before finishing the new season of his documentary series “Black Market.” The producers completed it with the help of some famous friends.
content: Days before the actor Michael K. Williams died, he stood in his penthouse apartment in the Williamsburg neighborhood of Brooklyn, hanging art on the wall and talking to a friend about what he wanted the future of his career to look like.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: A Healthy Danielle Collins Arrives in the Australian Open Semifinals
description: Less than a year after an endometriosis diagnosis led to the removal of a tennis-ball sized cyst, the 27th seeded American will play No. 7 Iga Swiatek in a semifinal.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — Danielle Collins has played exceptional tennis to reach the semifinals of the Australian Open, but only after achieving the victory of being “able to feel like a normal person.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Redwood Forest in California Is Returned to Native Tribes
description: Ownership of more than 500 acres of a forest in Mendocino County was returned to 10 sovereign tribes who will serve as guardians to “protect and heal” the land.
content: Tucked away in Northern California’s Mendocino County, the 523 acres of rugged forest is studded with the ghostlike stumps of ancient redwoods harvested during a logging boom that did away with over 90 percent of the species on the West Coast. But about 200 acres are still dense with old-growth redwoods that were spared from logging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: wherewithal
description: This word has appeared in 53 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Justice Breyer’s legacy: a liberal who rejected labels like ‘liberal.’
description: His voting over the years was generally similar to that of other Democratic appointees, if perhaps a little more conservative.
content: WASHINGTON — Justice Stephen G. Breyer, who is expected to retire after 27 years on the Supreme Court, leaves a legacy as a moderate liberal who worked hard to build consensus and protect the reputation of the court even as it moved sharply to the right in recent years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: How the Omicron Surge Is Straining California’s Health Care Workers
description: Staffing shortages, infected colleagues, exhaustion and burnout.
content: Even as the number of new coronavirus cases appears to be tapering off in California, the situation at our hospitals remains dire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Spoonfed
description: What do you think this image is communicating?
content: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Art Basel to Run New Paris Art Fair. Just Don’t Call it ‘Art Basel Paris.’
description: The new fair will run every October at the Grand Palais, a glittering venue that had been home to the FIAC contemporary art fair for the last 47 years.
content: Art Basel already runs glamour-filled art fairs in Switzerland, Miami Beach and Hong Kong. Now, it’s heading to Paris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2 Million Homes in California, Illinois and Kentucky
description: An 1892 Queen Anne in Alameda, an Arts and Crafts house in Kenilworth and a Classical Revival-style home in Prospect.
content: This house was designed by Charles Strong Shaner, an architect who worked extensively in Alameda in the late 19th century, primarily in an area known as the Gold Coast. The home, considered one of the finest examples of his work, has been featured on walking tours held by Alameda Museum. The seller, a collector of Victoriana, chose period-appropriate wallpaper for many of the rooms, and many of the light fixtures and hardware are from his collection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: Europe’s Split Over Omicron
description: The variant is cresting in some areas of Europe, but still skyrocketing in the east.
content: While the Omicron wave is beginning to crest in some areas of Europe, infection rates are still skyrocketing in other parts of the continent, particularly in the east.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Argument'
title: ‘Hell Hath No Fury Like a Voter Scorned’: What 14 Swing Voters Have to Say
description: Independents are “just physically, intellectually, emotionally tired,” says the pollster Frank Luntz.
content: A year into the Biden administration, most of us can agree on one thing: The United States remains a deeply divided nation, with polarizing opinions on all sides. But what about the voices from the middle, the independents? Swing voters are arguably one of the most consequential groups for the midterm elections, so we wanted to hear from them about how they view President Biden’s first year and the current state of American democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton
title: Melania Trump’s Auction of Hat Hit by Plunge in Cryptocurrency
description: The former first lady is selling a hat she wore for a visit by the French president amid volatility in the value of the digital currency being used for the auction.
content: Melania Trump’s much-discussed online auction, featuring a hat she wore at the White House during a 2018 visit by President Emmanuel Macron of France, ended up turning into a victim of the crash in the cryptocurrency market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson is among the leading candidates to succeed Justice Breyer.
description: Judge Jackson, 51, already successfully went through the Senate confirmation process last year.
content: Attention quickly turned on Wednesday to Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson as one of a small number of likely options who could fulfill President Biden’s pledge to nominate the first Black woman to the Supreme Court, after the disclosure that Justice Stephen G. Breyer has decided to retire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘Gomorrah’ Review: The End of TV’s Sleekest Italian Import
description: The final season of a gangster saga that combined brutal realism and high style arrives on HBO Max.
content: This review contains spoilers for “Gomorrah” Seasons 1-4 and the film “The Immortal.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kulish
title: Three New Faces to Help Steer the Gates Foundation
description: In the wake of Bill Gates and Melinda French Gates’s divorce, their foundation added members to its new governing board.
content: For the first time ever, the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation will be governed by a board that includes people who are not named Gates or Buffett. The question is whether they will have the power to change anything, or even want to.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman and Alana Holmberg
title: ‘What Do I Want From This Crazy Thing Called Life?’
description: A former Nike marketing executive turned mind-set coach is guiding the biggest stars at the Australian Open through the crucible of competition and fame.
content: Some of the most important moments of this year’s Australian Open took place far from a tennis court and had nothing to do with a certain vaccine-averse Serbian champion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai and Vimal Patel
title: Man Faces Weapons Charge in Texas Synagogue Standoff
description: The announcement came hours after two men had been arrested in Britain as part of an investigation by counterterrorism officers in which several people have been questioned.
content: A man who sold the gun that was used in a standoff in which four people were held hostage at a Texas synagogue this month has been charged with a federal firearm crime, the authorities said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Is the Great Resignation Overblown?
description: There’s evidence that rates of job quitting were higher in the past.
content: We’ve been bombarded by headlines about the Great Resignation. “Workers Are Quitting Their Jobs in Record Numbers.” “We’ve Become a Nation of Quitters.” “The Great Resignation Is Accelerating.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: Frogs Without Legs Regrow Leglike Limbs in New Experiment
description: Scientists describe a process by which African clawed frogs can regrow an imperfect but functional lost limb.
content: African clawed frogs are masters of putting themselves back together, handily regenerating lost tails and hind limbs, when they are tadpoles. But these powers dim with maturity. Wait for an adult frog to regrow a lopped-off limb and you’ll see only a tapered spike, more like a talon than a leg.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles and Miriam Jordan
title: A Surge at Sea: Migrants Seek Entry to the U.S. Aboard Flimsy Boats
description: Coast Guard officials said a search was still underway for 38 migrants missing after a boat capsized off Florida. The situation looked increasingly dire.
content: KEY WEST, Fla. — The maritime disaster that left rescuers still searching on Wednesday for 38 migrants lost at sea in the Florida Straits comes amid a surge in seaborne migration on both coasts as thousands of people board flimsy boats in a desperate attempt to reach the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Callahan
title: Do Neti Pots Really Work?
description: Nasal rinsing has been used for thousands of years to relieve sinus inflammation, congestion, allergy symptoms and more. Here’s what the evidence says.
content: To the uninitiated, the neti pot may seem like yet another wellness trend. After all, the teapot-like vessel was popularized in the United States by the celebrity surgeon Dr. Mehmet Oz, who called it a “nose bidet” on “The Oprah Winfrey Show” and has been criticized for promoting unproven supplements and health products.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Jessica Cheung, Mooj Zadie, Luke Vander Ploeg, Anita Badejo, John Ketchum, Paige Cowett, Marion Lozano and Corey Schreppel
title: We Need to Talk About Covid, Part 1
description: What a poll of Americans reveals about how ready the nation is to discuss living with the virus.
content: It appears that the United States may be at a turning point in the pandemic. The contagiousness of the Omicron variant has many people resigned to the fact that they probably will be infected; this variant is, relative to its predecessors and in most cases, milder; and there is universal vaccine access for those old enough to receive a shot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano
title: E.U. court throws out $1.2 billion antitrust fine against Intel.
description: Intel had been charged with paying illegal rebates to companies that used its semiconductors over rival Advanced Micro Devices.
content: In a defeat for the European Union’s tech antitrust efforts, a top court on Wednesday threw out a $1.2 billion fine issued against Intel more than a decade ago over practices to undercut a rival in the semiconductor industry.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Democrats Shy From a Return To Strict Limits
description: Quotation of the Day for January 26, 2022.
content: “I think everybody’s angry. It’s been two years now. We’re fatigued and ready to move on. I think a lot of the political vectors are reflecting that.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: The Year of American Disappointment
description: How we flirted with dynamism but tipped back into stagnation.
content: A year ago last week, Joe Biden was inaugurated as president of a country poised between two possible post-pandemic futures — one more dynamic and one more stagnant, one in which the shock of Covid-19 shoved American society out of our ruts and repetitions and one in which the pandemic only deepened our stagnation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan and Tracey Tully
title: Political Consultant Admits Hiring 2 Men to Kill Longtime Associate
description: Sean Caddle, whose clients have included prominent New Jersey Democrats, pleaded guilty in a scheme that led to a fatal stabbing.
content: A New Jersey political consultant admitted on Tuesday that he hired two men to kill a longtime associate who had worked for him on campaigns, and was found fatally stabbed in his burning apartment eight years ago, federal officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: SpaceX Rocket Part to Crash Into Moon 7 Years After Launch
description: The four-ton piece of the rocket hasn’t been heard from since it launched an American satellite called DSCOVR. It could make a 65-foot crater on the far side of the moon.
content: SpaceX will be getting to the moon a bit more than a month from now, far earlier than expected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shashank Bengali
title: Diplomats are meeting in Paris under the Normandy Format. We explain.
description: As part of the frenzied diplomatic effort to head off a conflagration in Ukraine, there has been a virtual summit between President Biden and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, as well as meetings between the top diplomats in Geneva, Brussels and Vienna.
content: As part of the frenzied diplomatic effort to head off a conflagration in Ukraine, there has been a virtual summit between President Biden and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, as well as meetings between the top diplomats in Geneva, Brussels and Vienna.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Judge Says States Can Investigate WinRed’s Fund-Raising Tactics
description: The Republican digital donation platform is facing inquiries from four state attorneys general into its use of prechecked boxes to withdraw donations automatically.
content: A federal judge in Minnesota on Wednesday dismissed a lawsuit filed by WinRed, a company that processes online donations for Republicans, that sought to block state attorneys general from investigating fund-raising tactics that have triggered complaints of fraud.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden made a campaign pledge to put a Black woman on the Supreme Court.
description: Biden, then a candidate with a struggling campaign for the Democratic nomination, made the promise ahead of his party’s primary in South Carolina.
content: The retirement of Justice Stephen G. Breyer will give President Biden a chance to make history, and to make good on his promise to put a Black woman on the Supreme Court, a campaign year pledge that helped revive his flagging campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Supreme Court, Russia, Paris Fashion Week: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell and Leah Askarinam
title: Confessions of a Liberal Heretic
description: Ruy Teixeira was co-author of one of the most influential political books of the 21st century. Now, he says, Democrats are getting its lessons all wrong.
content: A funny thing happened on the way to the emerging Democratic majority. Twenty years on, the co-authors of a hugely influential work on the subject acknowledge that their party took a detour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By André Wheeler
title: Can Hugo Boss Actually Be Cool?
description: The brand built by selling Wall Street suits is trying to reinvent itself for the post-office age.
content: On a sun-soaked day in Milan last fall, Hugo Boss said goodbye to the suit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: What to Do if You’ve Lost Your Covid-19 Vaccination Card
description: It never quite fit in your wallet, so it’s no surprise you may have misplaced it by now.
content: More than a year ago, when Covid-19 vaccines became available and jabs started going into arms, it became a point of pride for some people to show off a bandaged shoulder and a white Covid-19 Vaccination Record card.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farhad Manjoo
title: We Might Be in a Simulation. How Much Should That Worry Us?
description: Virtual reality is getting very real — real enough to call into question what “reality” even means.
content: Imagine that when your great-grandparents were teenagers, they got their hands on a groundbreaking new gadget, the world’s first fully immersive virtual-reality entertainment system. These weren’t those silly goggles you see everywhere now. This device was more Matrix-y — a stylish headband stuffed with electrodes that somehow tapped directly into the human brain’s perceptual system, replacing whatever a wearer saw, heard, felt, smelled and even tasted with new sensations ginned up by a machine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: The Fed is likely to say that the economy is at or near full employment.
description: Federal Reserve officials have been emphasizing rapid progress in the labor market as they prepare to raise interest rates.
content: Federal Reserve officials are expected to emphasize on Wednesday that their coming steps to slow economic support are based on more than just inflation worries: The job market has also staged a surprisingly rapid comeback.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: The ISIS Hostages: ‘These Children Should Not Have Been There’
description: About 700 boys have been held for years in a prison in Syria because their parents joined the Islamic State.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The boys in the prison sleep in groups of about 15 in cells with no windows, according to aid workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Which Republicans might support a Biden nominee for the Supreme Court? Few, if any.
description: Many Senate Republicans have, as a matter of course, opposed Mr. Biden’s nominees for seats on the lower federal courts.
content: WASHINGTON — Given the current level of political polarization, only a handful of Senate Republicans are likely to be in play as potential supporters of President Biden’s first Supreme Court nominee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Biden Administration Cancels Mining Leases Near Wilderness Area
description: The leases, reinstated during the Trump years, would have allowed a Chilean mining conglomerate to dig for copper and nickel near the Boundary Waters wilderness in Minnesota.
content: The Biden administration said Wednesday that it had canceled two mining leases that would have allowed a copper mine to be built near an area of pristine wilderness in Minnesota.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Staunch Critic of the N.Y.P.D. Grapples With Deaths of 2 Officers
description: Harlem Councilwoman Kristin Richardson Jordan, who has equated the policing system to slavery, is now considering how to deliver her message in a district mourning for two officers.
content: On one side of Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard in Harlem, dozens of candles and bouquets of flowers were clustered outside the 32nd Precinct station house after a shooting that would leave two officers dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Jim Drake, Who Captured Joe Namath on Broadway, Dies at 89
description: In his years with Sports Illustrated, he also photographed Muhammad Ali, Arnold Palmer and many of the other biggest sports stars of his time.
content: Jim Drake, a top photographer for Sports Illustrated whose pictures of Muhammad Ali, Joe Namath, Arnold Palmer and others, both in action and away from their fields of play, were among the magazine’s most indelible images from the 1960s to the ’80s, died on Jan. 10 at his home in Philadelphia. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: An Extraordinary Iceberg Is Gone, but Not Forgotten
description: A chunk of Antarctic ice that was one of the biggest icebergs ever seen has met its end near South Georgia. Scientists will be studying its effects on the ecosystem around the island for some time.
content: Perhaps you remember iceberg A68a, which enjoyed a few minutes of fame back in 2017 when it broke off an ice shelf on the Antarctic Peninsula. Hardly your everyday iceberg, it was one of the biggest ever seen, more than 100 miles long and 30 miles wide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas
title: Olavo de Carvalho, Bolsonaro’s Far-Right Guru, Dies at 74
description: He was the intellectual leader of Brazil’s far-right movement and a conspiracy theorist who mocked the pandemic. He died days after announcing he had Covid.
content: Olavo de Carvalho, a far-right Brazilian pundit and self-proclaimed philosopher who became the political guru of President Jair Bolsonaro by warning of a globalist plot to spread communism across the world, died on Monday outside Richmond, Va. He was 74.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Samantha Facciolo
title: Progress Comes Only With Practice
description: The lessons my grandfather taught me while we solved crossword puzzles went well beyond putting letters in squares.
content: My grandfather completed crossword puzzles the same way he solved problems in life: Weighing options, approaching a problem with clarity and staying humble were the best way forward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Here’s why Republicans can’t filibuster President Biden’s Supreme Court nominee.
description: Though Democrats do not need to worry about Republicans using a filibuster against the forthcoming nominee, winning confirmation is no slam dunk.
content: While Democrats failed last week to upend the Senate filibuster to pass new voting rights laws, they do not have to change any rules to thwart a Republican filibuster against a Supreme Court nominee — those changes have already been made.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Teresa Reichlen to Retire From New York City Ballet
description: A principal dancer since 2009, Reichlen will make her final appearance in George Balanchine’s one-act “Swan Lake” on Feb. 19.
content: Teresa Reichlen, a New York City Ballet principal dancer for the past 13 years, announced on Wednesday that she would retire from the company and give her farewell performance in George Balanchine’s “Swan Lake.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: Kurdish-Led Forces End Prison Siege, Defeating ISIS Fighters
description: The six-day battle put a spotlight on the humanitarian and security issues left unresolved after the Islamic State’s so-called caliphate was destroyed.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — After six days of deadly battles, the Kurdish-led militia that had been battling Islamic State fighters for control of a prison in northeastern Syria retook the facility on Wednesday, ending one of the most audacious attacks by the jihadist group since the collapse of its so-called caliphate nearly three years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Macron’s Comments on Algeria Resonate as Elections Loom
description: The French president acknowledged the suffering of colonists who fled Algeria after the war of independence, a group that has long voted heavily in favor of the right in France.
content: PARIS — President Emmanuel Macron of France, addressing a community that has been fertile ground for the far right ahead of presidential elections this spring, on Wednesday acknowledged the suffering of the French and European colonists who fled Algeria after the 1954-62 war of independence and of their descendants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Even Low Levels of Soot Can Be Deadly to Older People, Research Finds
description: The four-year air pollution study, which followed 68.5 million older Americans, was the first of its kind.
content: WASHINGTON — Older Americans who regularly breathe even low levels of pollution from smokestacks, automobile exhaust, wildfires and other sources face a greater chance of dying early, according to a major study released Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: A Shorter ‘Long Day’s Journey,’ Now With N95s
description: The Eugene O’Neill classic, set in 1912, is just as powerful in Robert O’Hara’s revival, set in our own age of disease and lockdown.
content: Eugene O’Neill, whose insanely detailed stage directions for “Long Day’s Journey Into Night” specify even the titles of the books on the shelves, somehow forgot to mention the Purell. Also the N95s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: Palestinian American Held by Israel Died of Heart Attack, Autopsy Shows
description: The coroner’s report suggested that Omar Assad, 78, had a stress-induced heart attack as a result of injuries he sustained while in Israeli military custody.
content: JERUSALEM — A 78-year-old Palestinian American man died this month from a stress-induced heart attack brought on by injuries sustained while he was detained by Israeli soldiers, according to an autopsy report, obtained by The New York Times on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Democrats Renew Push to Pass Industrial Policy Bill to Counter China
description: A major competitiveness bill passed the Senate last year with bipartisan support, only to stall. Democrats hope to revive it in the House, but first they will have to bridge big differences.
content: WASHINGTON — Biden administration officials and Democrats in Congress are pushing to revive stalled legislation that would pour billions of dollars into scientific research and development and shore up domestic manufacturing, amid deep differences on Capitol Hill about the best way to counter China and confront persistent supply chain woes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: Their Characters Are Stuck, but the Filmmakers Are Anything But
description: Sujata Day and Agam Darshi, who hadn’t met until their movies were done, each portray women of South Asian descent who stay home to care for parents.
content: A young woman shows early glints of genius — but her parent falls ill, so she never leaves the nest, forced to stay behind to help out. Then something happens, a tipping point, and her absent siblings return. There is tension, conflict, reconciliation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Rosenberg
title: From Pedestal to Petri Dish, Liz Larner Makes Sculptures for a New Era
description: The artist, whose installations and sculptures run from microscopic to immense, is having a midcareer survey at SculptureCenter, her largest exhibition since 2001.
content: Liz Larner’s exuberant midcareer survey at SculptureCenter begins with a bang, or a few of them: a motorized steel ball, tethered to a rotating column, smashes into the gallery wall. The piece is called “Corner Basher,” and its speed is controlled by the viewer; turning the dial all the way up results in an increasingly loud and frequent thwacking noise, a growing dent in the architecture and a gleeful sense of transgression.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cindy Hirschfeld
title: For Skiers, a Winter of Discontent
description: With resorts having trouble hiring and employees calling out sick, visitors have been frustrated by idled lifts, limited services and closed terrain. Some of the biggest complaints have come from Epic Pass holders.
content: “Is it just me, or do some of the lifties look older this season?” asked my husband as we rode a chairlift at Snowmass, in Colorado — our local resort — a couple of days after Christmas. I reminded him that during the holidays, the Aspen Skiing Company’s executive team comes out to Snowmass and its other three ski areas to drive shuttles, work at on-mountain restaurants and, yes, help load lifts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Farago
title: Charles Ray Is Pushing Sculpture to Its Limit
description: With four surveys, the challenging Los Angeles artist has redefined his art form in a flat-screen world.
content: I was looking up at the head, but I was mistaken. Charles Ray was instructing me to look at the foot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zengerle
title: To Hell and Back, Then to CNN
description: Once an ordinary citizen stumbles into the culture war, it can be hard to get back out. Just ask Michael Fanone.
content: Michael Fanone seemed very out of place. It was the first anniversary of the Jan. 6 insurrection, and CNN was commemorating the occasion with blanket coverage. A year earlier, Fanone was a 40-year-old Metropolitan Police Department (M.P.D.) officer trying to hold off an angry mob outside the United States Capitol. The rioters pulled him from a tunnel and down a set of steps, pummeled him with their fists and their feet and even the staff of an American flag and tased him numerous times; in the melee, he suffered both a heart attack and a traumatic brain injury. Now Fanone was outside the Capitol again, on the set of CNN’s “New Day” morning show, sitting next to its hosts, John Berman and Brianna Keilar. He wore faded jeans and a red-and-black plaid parka, in stark contrast to Berman’s and Keilar’s news-anchor attire. With his heavy beard and a turtleneck of tattoos peeking out from underneath his collar, he looked like some sort of punk lumberjack. He sounded like one too. When Keilar asked him to share some of the conversations he was having with police officers as the anniversary approached, Fanone acidly noted that the U.S. Capitol Police “have to walk the same halls as some of these insurrectionist members of Congress,” before adding, “I couldn’t imagine sharing a work space with those jackasses.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Broadway Grosses Fall, but Average Attendance Rises, as Shows Close
description: Theaters were a bit more crowded, but there were fewer shows running as several closed amid the spread of the Omicron variant.
content: The percentage of seats filled on Broadway was up last week, but overall box office grosses fell, as some of the industry’s softest shows closed and the survivors reduced prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: The Narcotic Pleasures of #Cleantok
description: Why is it so calming to watch someone organizing a fridge?
content: In the lowest depths of my pandemic torpor, one of the few things that would lift my spirits was watching organizing videos on TikTok. In 2020, while my kids were doing distance learning, I occasionally closed my bedroom door to muffle the sounds of at-home third grade and pre-K and submerged into the tidy, satisfying world of another mom cleaning and then restocking her spotless refrigerator with a colorful array of fruits, vegetables and adorable mini pepperoni.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski and Jason Horowitz
title: The World Awaits Putin’s Word on Ukraine, but on That, He Is Silent
description: The Russian president appears on camera almost daily, talking about things like cryptocurrency, green energy and the World’s Fair. But not about Ukraine.
content: MOSCOW — Amid all the fear and guesswork this month over the possibility that President Vladimir V. Putin could soon order an attack on Ukraine, one man has been conspicuously silent: Mr. Putin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Germany, Apart
description: Donald Trump’s shadow hangs over the Ukraine crisis.
content: Donald Trump has made a habit of deriding the U.S. alliance with Western Europe. He described NATO — the American-led alliance with Europe that dates to the 1940s — as “obsolete” and said that Americans were “schmucks” for financing it. He mused about withdrawing the U.S. from NATO and often spoke more positively about Russia than about longtime American allies like Germany and France.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: The I.M.F. urges El Salvador to end its embrace of crypto as Bitcoin tumbles.
description: The price of Bitcoin has fallen more than 50 percent from its peak in November, which could prove costly for institutions that have bought into digital currencies.
content: The International Monetary Fund urged El Salvador on Tuesday to end its recognition of Bitcoin as legal tender. Adopting a cryptocurrency in this way “entails large risks for financial and market integrity, financial stability and consumer protection,” the fund’s executive board wrote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Cawthorn Challenge Raises the Question: Who Is an ‘Insurrectionist’?
description: The challenge to Representative Madison Cawthorn’s re-election bid could set a precedent to challenge other Republicans who encouraged the Jan. 6 attack.
content: WASHINGTON — A group of lawyers is working to disqualify from the ballot a right-wing House Republican who cheered on the Jan. 6 rioters unless he can prove he is not an “insurrectionist,” disqualified by the Constitution from holding office, in a case with implications for other officeholders and potentially former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: He’s a Doctor. He’s an Actor. He’s an Indie Heartthrob.
description: How does Anders Danielsen Lie of “The Worst Person in the World” juggle careers in acting and medicine? “This has been my ongoing identity crisis,” he said.
content: Actors have a long history of indulging in side projects: Some use their off time to write books, while others even front rock bands. But it’s fair to say that few thespians navigate a dual career quite like Anders Danielsen Lie, who currently stars as a lingering love interest in both “Bergman Island” and “The Worst Person in the World” — an indie-film doubleheader that prompted one critic to dub him “the art house’s next great ex-boyfriend” — while still working full-time as a doctor in Oslo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oscar Lopez
title: Killing Spree Spurs Outrage Among Journalists in Mexico
description: The killing of three media workers in less than a month triggered protests in cities across the county this week demanding an end to the violence.
content: MEXICO CITY — In a country where the brutal killings of journalists are almost routine, a recent spree of violent deaths has provoked a rare outpouring of public outrage among reporters and everyday citizens alike in Mexico.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Killing Jolts Sweden’s Rap Scene
description: A conversation about hip-hop’s evolution in the country, and how a high-profile shooting thrust the music into the spotlight.
content: Einar, the Swedish rapper who in the last few years had become one of the most dominant performers in the country’s hip-hop scene, as well as a major pop figure, was shot and killed last October. The case remains unsolved.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Bring Back the Free World
description: Putin wants to divide and conquer. We shouldn’t let him.
content: At some point in the last 30 years, the concept of the “free world” fell out of favor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin and Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Can CNN’s Hiring Spree Get People to Pay for Streaming News?
description: The network’s boss, Jeff Zucker, tries to make up for lost time by signing Chris Wallace, Audie Cornish and Eva Longoria.
content: A couple of months ago, CNN’s forthcoming streaming channel was perceived as little more than a curiosity in the television news business: just another cable dinosaur trying to make the uneasy transition into the digital future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: How the Computer Chip Shortage Could Incite a U.S. Conflict With China
description: A war game and study by a think tank illustrate how dependent the world is on Taiwan’s semiconductor foundries.
content: WASHINGTON — The war game scenario conducted by a Washington think tank began with a sudden failure at three Taiwanese semiconductor foundries that make high-end computer chips used in such items as smartphones, automobiles and military equipment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cora Engelbrecht
title: The U.S.-Kurd alliance in Syria has a tangled history.
description: American and Kurdish-led forces once beat back the Islamic State in Syria. Now they are fighting together again.
content: For U.S. forces in Syria, an on-again off-again alliance is very much on again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: New Research Hints at 4 Factors That May Increase Chances of Long Covid
description: If further study confirms the findings, they could lead to ways to prevent and treat the complex condition.
content: It is one of many mysteries about long Covid: Who is more prone to developing it? Are some people more likely than others to experience physical, neurological or cognitive symptoms that can emerge, or linger for, months after their coronavirus infections have cleared?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Justice Leondra R. Kruger of the California Supreme Court is a possible nominee.
description: At 45, she would be younger than all but one of the current justices were when they were nominated.
content: Justice Leondra R. Kruger of the California Supreme Court has many of the qualifications typical of nominees for vacancies on the U.S. Supreme Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Veronique Greenwood
title: Your Body’s Thirst Messenger Is in an Unexpected Place
description: Scientists traced how a mouse’s brain gets the signal that it had enough to drink. Something similar may happen in humans.
content: Few pleasures compare to a long cool drink on a hot day. As a glass of water or other tasty drink makes its way to your digestive tract, your brain is tracking it — but how? Scientists have known for some time that thirst is controlled by neurons that send an alert to put down the glass when the right amount has been guzzled. What precisely tells them that it is time, though, is still a bit mysterious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Boeing posts a $4.2 billion quarterly loss as delays persist in 787 production.
description: The aircraft maker took a $3.5 billion charge because of problems in addressing Dreamliner flaws to the F.A.A.’s satisfaction.
content: Boeing reported a $3.5 billion charge in the final three months of last year from prolonged delays in making and delivering its 787 Dreamliner jet, driving the company to a bruising $4.2 billion loss for the quarter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Thursday Briefing: U.S. Responds to Russia
description: Antony Blinken, the secretary of state, said the U.S. offered a “serious diplomatic path forward.”
content: The U.S. and NATO gave formal responses on Wednesday to Russia’s demands that NATO pull back forces from Eastern Europe and bar Ukraine from ever joining the alliance. The U.S. response “sets out a serious diplomatic path forward should Russia choose it,” the secretary of state, Antony Blinken, said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Israeli study finds the rate of heart problems in vaccinated boys is slightly higher than expected.
description: Myocarditis, or inflammation of the heart muscle, occurred in 1 of 12,361 boys aged 12 to 15 within a week of receiving a second dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine, researchers found.
content: Boys aged 12 to 15 have a small but increased risk of heart problems after receiving a second dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine, Israeli researchers reported on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Fashion Dispenses a Happy Little Pill
description: After two years of pandemic limbo, the men’s shows in Paris offered up a mood elevator.
content: PARIS — It probably isn’t surprising that a current of conservatism was seen in the men’s wear shows here, a link connecting storied labels like Dior and Hermès, where the designers Kim Jones and Véronique Nichanian produced fall collections that highlighted their design chops by doubling down on heritage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Did We Miss Biden’s Most Important Remark About Russia?
description: Putin has something bigger to worry about at home than anything that happens in Ukraine.
content: Pretty much every crucial line in President Biden’s recent marathon news conference has been dissected by now — except one, the one that may turn out to be the most prescient. You had to be listening closely because it went by fast. It was when Biden told President Vladimir Putin that Russia has something much more important to worry about than whether Ukraine looks East or West — namely, “a burning tundra that will not freeze again naturally.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe and Karen Weise
title: Amazon pays $2.25 million to settle a price-fixing investigation.
description: An Amazon program guaranteed sellers a minimum price while offering a potential upside if an algorithm determined that customers were willing to pay more
content: Amazon settled a price-fixing investigation by the Washington State attorney general’s office on Wednesday, agreeing to pay $2.25 million and end a program that gave it control over the prices of products supplied by third-party sellers on its marketplace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Weekly Accessible Learning Activities: Fictional Houses, Fascinating Animals, Favorite Technology
description: Each week we spotlight five student activities created for a broad range of learners based on reporting in The New York Times.
content: Each Wednesday we shine a spotlight on five student activities that support a broad range of learners. Below you’ll find learning activities based on the family home from “Home Alone,” recent animal discoveries, useful tech tools, an intriguing photograph and maps showing where people of Asian descent live in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: It Started as a Romantic Idyll. It Ended With a Stack of Corpses.
description: In “Reckless Girls,” by Rachel Hawkins, a vacation on a remote atoll in the South Pacific goes very, very wrong.
content: It’s a new year, which means a new crop of thrillers to provide some delicious diversionary relief from the sometimes less thrilling things going on in the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: A Legal Challenge to Rules Against Legal Advice from Nonlawyers
description: A nonprofit wants to train volunteers to help consumers defend themselves in debt collection cases.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll look at a lawsuit about legal advice from nonlawyers. We’ll also look at a dog run that was linked — on social media, at least — to the bacterial disease leptospirosis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Vestas, a Danish wind giant, warns of supply chain turbulence.
description: The company, the world’s largest maker of wind turbines, said pandemic delays in China and the rising cost of steel were hindering earnings.
content: Wind energy projects are being proposed around the world to help meet climate goals, but the largest maker of turbines is finding that supply chain issues and pandemic lockdowns are hampering wind farm construction and hurting financial results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: In Some Markets, Cooler Heads Are Prevailing
description: Wild swings in stocks haven’t shown up in other assets.
content: Stock markets took investors on another wild ride yesterday, plunging, recovering and then dropping again. Futures are looking up today, but what does that mean after a week of such swings in stocks?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Australian Government Buys Copyright to Indigenous Flag
description: The flag had been at the center of a dispute, but the move allows anyone to reproduce its design without seeking permission or paying a fee.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — When Laura Thompson, an Indigenous businesswoman, received a cease-and-desist letter in 2019 telling her to stop selling clothing that used the design of the Aboriginal flag because it violated the copyright, she was shocked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Justice Dept. Is Reviewing Role of Fake Trump Electors, Top Official Says
description: Lisa O. Monaco, the deputy attorney general, told CNN that she could not “say anything more on ongoing investigations.”
content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department is investigating the fake slates of electors that falsely declared Donald J. Trump the victor of the 2020 election in seven swing states that Joseph R. Biden Jr. had in fact won, a top agency official said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: Can Laziness Be a Good Thing?
description: Do you ever sit around and do nothing? Do you feel bad about it, or is rest a priority in your life?
content: Do you ever sit around and do nothing — or nothing that is tied to a concrete outcome or goal?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: After 16 Years in ‘Hadestown,’ Anaïs Mitchell Emerges With a New Album
description: The singer-songwriter fully plunged into her acclaimed theater project. Since then, her life changed wildly — and she recaptured the desire to record her own music.
content: BRISTOL, Vt. — Eight years ago, shortly before the birth of her first child, the musician Anaïs Mitchell was instructed in a hypnobirthing class to envision her “happy place,” and was flooded with a sense memory from her rural Vermont childhood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: Two Years After Kobe’s Death, Jerry West About the ‘Shock and Sadness’
description: West, the former Lakers icon and general manager, said the losses of Bryant and his friend Elgin Baylor, who died last year, have made him more introspective.
content: Jerry West spent a lifetime becoming one of the most decorated figures in N.B.A. history as a player and an executive, but these days, his routine includes daily workouts, coronavirus testing and a regular gin rummy game with some friends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Tesla reports record yearly profit but warns that supply problems persist.
description: The carmaker had a profit of $5.5 billion as sales of its electric vehicles kept soaring, especially in China and Europe.
content: Tesla said Wednesday that its profit leapt more than sixfold last year to $5.5 billion, the highest total in its 19-year history, as sales soared further, especially in Europe and China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey and Ben Rothenberg
title: The Spotlight Shifted Away From Peng Shuai. Some Players and Fans Want It Back.
description: A central question, “Where is Peng Shuai?”, has represented concern for the star but also points to related questions about the future of tennis in China.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — Xiao, a Chinese-born and Melbourne-based artist, was disturbed that the plight of the Chinese tennis star Peng Shuai had slipped off the radar ahead of the first Grand Slam tournament of the year. So she designed a T-shirt, and much to the dismay of Australian Open organizers, wore it to Melbourne Park.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maia Szalavitz
title: Treating Addiction as a Crime Doesn’t Work. What Oregon Is Doing Just Might.
description: The promise of Oregon’s drug decriminalization plan.
content: Morgan Godvin arrived at the Multnomah County Inverness jail in Oregon in June 2013. She had volunteered to be locked up during a drug-court appearance for felony heroin possession. Like many Americans, she believed that incarceration would help her recover. But when she requested her prescribed addiction medication, the nurse “just laughed,” she said. Ms. Godvin was denied the gold standard treatment for opioid use disorder and was left to kick cold turkey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: A Singer Brings His Authentic Self to the Philharmonic
description: Anthony Roth Costanzo, a restless countertenor with a vast network of collaborators, has planned a wide-reaching festival.
content: Anthony Roth Costanzo was never just going to step onstage and sing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: E.P.A. Chief Vows to ‘Do Better’ to Protect Poor Communities
description: The Environmental Protection Agency on Wednesday will announce stepped-up enforcement and monitoring to help disadvantaged communities struggling with polluted air and water.
content: WASHINGTON — Michael S. Regan, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, traveled to Jackson, Miss., in November to discuss the city’s poor water quality at an elementary school where children have to drink bottled water and use portable restrooms outside the building.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: At the Australian Open, the Last Men Standing Have Been Through the Wringer
description: The men’s singles semifinals will feature No. 6 Rafael Nadal against No. 7 Matteo Berrettini, and No. 2 Daniil Medvedev against No. 4 Stefanos Tsitsipas.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — None of the men’s singles semifinalists at the Australian Open has made it this far unscathed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: A flurry of Russian military drills.
content: Russia announced a flurry of military drills yesterday across its vast territory, from the Pacific Ocean to the country’s western flank near Ukraine, including joint drills with the Chinese fleet in the Arabian Sea. The announcement followed a series of military moves made by the U.S. and NATO this week aimed at deterring a Russian incursion into Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Wong
title: New York City schools will shorten isolation to 5 days for most students who test positive.
description: Longer isolation will still be required for some preschoolers. The change brings the school system’s policy in line with recent federal and state guidance.
content: New York City’s public schools will halve the minimum required isolation period for students who test positive for the coronavirus, and the quarantine rule for unvaccinated students who are exposed to the virus, to five days from 10, officials at the Department of Education said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Jana Bennett, Former Director of BBC Television, Dies at 66
description: An American-born executive who transformed the presentation of science on TV and was considered one of the most influential women in her industry.
content: Jana Bennett, an influential American-born broadcast executive and program-maker at the British Broadcasting Corporation who helped redefine the presentation of science on television, died on Jan. 11 at her home in Oxfordshire, England. She was 66.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Requiem for Party Dresses Lost
description: The return never quite happened. So what do we wear now? Schiaparelli, Chanel and Dior grapple gorgeously with the question.
content: PARIS — The last time the couture collections took place was the first time most of the fashion world, that traveling circus that reunites only during shows, had seen one another after more than a year of pandemic trauma.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Benveniste
title: The Meaning and History of Memes
description: Internet culture is saturated with memes, but how would you explain a meme to someone who doesn’t get it?
content: Memes didn’t start with the internet. Some linguists argue that humans have used memes to communicate for centuries. Memes are widely known as conduits for cultural conversations and an opportunity to participate in internet trends (trust us, the Times is on it). Even if you’re not extremely online, you’ve probably participated in a meme trend, knowingly or not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Tingley
title: Counting Covid-19 Cases Doesn’t Capture the Pandemic’s Impact
description: There’s virtually no aspect of our lives that the pandemic hasn’t changed. We’re just starting to understand some of the data on public health.
content: At some point, hopefully soon, infections from the latest variant to emerge during the Covid-19 pandemic will subside, and it will be easy for many Americans to believe that they made it through another surge unscathed. But in fact, we don’t have a simple way of measuring the long-term impact of Omicron — or the pandemic as a whole — on everyone’s health or what kinds of consequences it will have on our health care system. “Even from the early days of the pandemic,” says Caleb Alexander, a professor of epidemiology and medicine at the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health, “it’s been clear that there are going to be any number of large collateral effects.” What’s less clear at this point is how to even define those effects, let alone quantify them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Site of a Legend
description: Michael Schlossberg’s puzzle is crystal clear.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — I am perpetually in awe of the things that crossword constructors identify as fodder for crossword themes. Freddie Cheng, for example, had a realization about a poster he saw at his gym, and Kate Hawkins noticed that MICHAEL CRICHTON contained the word “circle” backward and made a puzzle about it. Today, we have another tale of taking inspiration from an unexpected place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcus J. Moore
title: The Evolution of Black Music, and a Man’s Soul, in One Show
description: The new show “Black No More,” inspired by a 1931 satirical novel about race relations, has “the point of view of people who are very much products of now.”
content: A Black man in New York City, during the Harlem Renaissance, is hoping for a life without bigotry. This is Harlem after all, a Black enclave, the epicenter of culture and creativity. Here, he’d have an easier time in getting along.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed Signals Rate Increase in March, Citing Inflation and Strong Job Market
description: Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair, said the central bank could raise rates imminently as officials cut back help for the economy.
content: Federal Reserve officials signaled on Wednesday that they were on track to raise interest rates in March, given that inflation has been running far above policymakers’ target and that labor market data suggests employees are in short supply.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Stewart Rhodes, Oath Keepers Leader, Is Denied Bail on Sedition Charge
description: A federal judge said Mr. Rhodes, who was charged in connection with the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, was a flight risk partly because of “elaborate escape tunnels” in his backyard.
content: Stewart Rhodes, the leader of the Oath Keepers militia charged with seditious conspiracy in connection with the attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6 last year, was denied bail on Wednesday by a federal judge in Texas who said he was a flight risk partly because of the “elaborate escape tunnels” he had installed in his backyard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eleanor Stanford
title: For This Tearful TV Potter, It’s All About the Clay
description: Keith Brymer Jones has judged amateur ceramic makers’ work on “The Great Pottery Throw Down” since 2015. When it’s good, it still moves him.
content: LONDON — When the potter Keith Brymer Jones was approached to front a new TV show about making ceramics, he was skeptical. “Pottery, on television? Really? It would be like watching paint dry,” he recalled thinking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Giulia Heyward
title: The Fight for Substitute Teachers
description: Schools deploy creative measures to staff classrooms.
content: I’m Giulia Heyward, and since this school year began, I’ve covered the nationwide labor shortage affecting so many of the country’s schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: The federal consumer bureau wants to stamp out what it calls ‘junk fees.’
description: Late payment charges, hotel resort fees and other tacked-on expenses collectively add billions to what Americans pay for goods and services.
content: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is preparing to crack down on what it calls junk fees — late payment charges, hotel resort fees and other tacked-on expenses that collectively add billions to what Americans pay for goods and services.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Why an Easy Energy Fix Is Being Delayed
description: LED lights are far more efficient, but there’s still money to be made from older bulbs.
content: It’s one of the simplest, easiest and cheapest ways to drastically shrink your electricity bills, and your climate footprint: switch out your old incandescent lights for energy-efficient LED bulbs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt
title: A top Biden ally has a favored candidate to replace Justice Breyer: Judge J. Michelle Childs.
description: Representative James E. Clyburn, Democrat of South Carolina, supports a little-known federal judge in his home state: J. Michelle Childs.
content: Days after President Biden was sworn in last year, one of his top congressional allies went to the White House with the name of a judge he believed should be appointed to the Supreme Court.
source.name: The New York Times

content: Love is hard to find these days. Apps turn people into play things. The pandemic is fatal for vibes. Adele reigns atop the Billboard charts, singing her tales of longing and woe.

title: Corrections: Jan. 26, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Jan. 26, 2022.
content: The “Headline in History” article on Sunday misidentified Apple’s first personal computer. The Apple 1 was Apple’s first personal computer, not the Macintosh.

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Air Fry a Cheesecake
description: Chicken Parmesan, garlicky brussels sprouts and more recipes for the beloved countertop appliance.
content: Good morning. Do you have an air fryer? Millions of Americans do and, as Christina Morales reports for The Times this week, the device may be supplanting the microwave and humble toaster oven as the nation’s favored countertop cooking device, this year’s electric pressure cooker or 12-button blender. “The air fryer,” one of the home cooks Christina spoke to for the article said, “is here to stay.”
source.name: The New York Times
